summary: This is a Federal Bureau of Prisons memorandum from the Federal Correctional Institution, dated August 10, 2019, detailing the discovery and emergency response to inmate Jeffrey Epstein's apparent suicide by hanging in his cell. It includes concerning admissions from staff about failure to complete required rounds.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found unresponsive in his cell after apparently hanging himself; the subject of the emergency medical response.

persons.name: Operations Lieutenant
persons.context: The recipient of the memorandum, to whom the report is addressed.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: The intended recipient of the memorandum.

events.title: Discovery of Jeffrey Epstein's Apparent Suicide
events.description: At approximately 6:33 A.M., Special Housing Unit (SHU) officers announced a medical emergency. Inmate Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell Z06-220 on L-tier, having apparently hung himself. CPR was administered continuously, 911 was called at 6:35 a.m., and he was transferred to an EMS ambulance at 7:10 a.m. for transport to Beekman Hospital.

events.title: Admission of Failed Security Rounds
events.description: During the emergency, a staff member admitted to the reporting officer that they "did not complete the 3am nor 5am rounds," stating "we messed up" and "I messed up."

locations: Cell Z06-220, L-tier, Special Housing Unit (SHU)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at approximately 6:33 A.M. on August 10, 2019, after apparently hanging himself.
CPR was administered continuously from discovery until EMT staff took over at 6:43 a.m.; he was transferred to an EMS ambulance at 7:10 a.m. for transport to Beekman Hospital.
A staff member admitted to the reporting officer that required security rounds at 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. were not completed, stating "we messed up" and "I messed up."
The document is a confidential internal Bureau of Prisons memorandum detailing the immediate aftermath and emergency response to Epstein's death.
The report suggests a potential failure in standard prison protocols (rounds) that may have contributed to the incident not being prevented.
